story.headline: The Pantanal Is Burning: World's Largest Tropical Wetland in Crisis
story.summary: The Pantanal, the world's largest tropical wetland spanning Brazil, Bolivia, and Paraguay, experienced record-breaking fires in 2020 and 2024 that burned over 25% of the ecosystem. Prolonged drought and rising temperatures are transforming this biodiversity hotspot.
story.climateImpact: Fires in the Pantanal release stored carbon from peat soils and vegetation, while drought reduces the wetland's capacity to function as a carbon sink and water regulator.
causeEffect: Climate-driven drought reduces water levels in the wetland
Dry conditions make vegetation highly flammable
Agricultural fires escape into the wetland
Peat and organic soil fires release stored carbon
story.scaleContext: The Pantanal spans 150,000 kmÂ² and is home to over 4,700 plant and animal species. In 2020, fires burned approximately 30% of the entire biome. 2024 fires were on track to exceed this.
story.outlook: Continued warming and deforestation in upstream watersheds could permanently alter the Pantanal's flood cycle, converting wetland to degraded savanna.
